instruction: How do I fix the disk quota issue?
response:
We all have a limited amount of disk space we are allowed to use in our home directories.  To see the current usage, type the following into a terminal:

  quota -s

The first number is the space used, the second is the limit.  When we are out of space, we'll often see a * next to the number.

The following command (entered into a terminal on a cs lab machine) will help identify where the quota is being used:

  du -m ~ | sort -n

This command will show the disk usage, in megabytes, for all the directories inside your home directory, sorted numerically.

You may find that vscode is using a lot of disk space for temporary files.  Feel free to get rid of vscode directories.  For example:

  cd ~/.cache/vscode-cpptools/
  rm -rf ipch

Be careful with "rm -rf"-- there is no undo!

instruction: What is the difference between absolute and relative file paths?
response:
When we specify a file or directory on the command line (in the terminal, that is, in the shell) we can do so in two ways.  We can give the name in a form that is always going to be the same, regardless of what we have done before, like this:

   ~/sd

In this pathname, we are using the ~ to represent the (absolute) path to the home directory, and then, within that, we are referring to the sd subdirectory.  Some other examples of absolute pathnames would be:

  ~/sd/hw01/daily.cpp
  ~/cs2
  /usr/local/cs/cs251

Anything that starts with ~ or / will be an absolute pathname.

On the other hand, we can also specify relative path names, that is, names that are relative to our current location in the file system.  Say for example that, when we first logged in, we want to go to our hw01 directory, like this (using an absolute pathname):

  cd ~/sd/hw01

If we wanted to go to the hw02 directory, we could do so with a relative pathname like this:

  cd ../hw02

The .. means the parent directory, which, in this case, is the sd directory, and the hw02 subdirectory is assumed to be inside it.  From there, if we wanted to go to the cs2 directory, we could use another relative pathname, like this:

  cd ../../cs2

In this case, the parent of the parent of the current directory is the home directory, and the cs2 directory is found within it.

If we say something like:

  cd sd

Then that is a relative pathname, so it will only work if we are already in a directory that has a subdirectory named sd.  So if we are in the home directory, the command "cd sd" will work fine, but otherwise not.

instruction: What does the ls terminal command do?
response:
ls - lists all the items in the current directory, including files and subdirectories.
In addition, ls -l allows you to see more information about each file and directory in the current directory, such as owner and group privileges. ls -a shows hidden files and directories. (Note you can combine flags, so you could use ls -al to list all files (including hidden ones) with additional information).

instruction: What does the cp terminal command do?
response:
cp copies items from one place to another using absolute or relative paths. Here is an example:

cp ~/hw01/daily.cpp ~/hw02

This copies daily.cpp from the hw01 directory to the hw02 directory.

You can copy multiple files at the same time (as long as they are going to the same destination): 

cp ~/hw01/myProgram.cpp ~/Documents/myTextFile.txt ~/Pictures/myPhoto.png [as many files as you’d like, separated by spaces] ~/destinationDirectory

To copy multiple files, put the absolute or relative paths of each file you want to copy first. You can put as many files as you’d like here. Then, make sure to end with the path of the directory you want to copy the files to.

You can move multiple files at the same time (as long as they are going to the same destination).

You can also use mv to rename files:

mv ~/hw01/daily.cpp ~/hw01/newname.cpp

This “moves” daily.cpp from the hw01 directory to the hw01 directory named as newname.cpp, renaming the file.

instruction: What does the rm terminal command do?
response:
rm deletes files. WARNING: you do not get a warning before deleting, if you use this command the file will be gone forever.

rm ~/hw01/daily.cpp

This permanently deletes daily.cpp from the hw01 directory.

rm -r - This deletes things in directories. The -r stands for recursive, meaning that it deletes not only the directory but everything in the directory. Use this very carefully, there is no undo.

rm -r ~/hw01

This deletes everything in the hw01 directory.

rmdir - this deletes empty directories. If you want to delete a directory with stuff in it, first use rm -r and then use rmdir.

rmdir ~/hw01

This deletes the (empty) hw01 directory.

rm deletes files. WARNING: you do not get a warning before deleting, if you use this command the file will be gone forever.

rm ~/hw01/daily.cpp

This permanently deletes daily.cpp from the hw01 directory.

rm -r - This deletes things in directories. The -r stands for recursive, meaning that it deletes not only the directory but everything in the directory. Use this very carefully, there is no undo.

rm -r ~/hw01

This deletes everything in the hw01 directory.

rmdir - this deletes empty directories. If you want to delete a directory with stuff in it, first use rm -r and then use rmdir.

rmdir ~/hw01

This deletes the (empty) hw01 directory.

rm deletes files. WARNING: you do not get a warning before deleting, if you use this command the file will be gone forever.

rm ~/hw01/daily.cpp

This permanently deletes daily.cpp from the hw01 directory.

rm -r - This deletes things in directories. The -r stands for recursive, meaning that it deletes not only the directory but everything in the directory. Use this very carefully, there is no undo.

rm -r ~/hw01

This deletes everything in the hw01 directory.

rmdir - this deletes empty directories. If you want to delete a directory with stuff in it, first use rm -r and then use rmdir.

rmdir ~/hw01

This deletes the (empty) hw01 directory.

rmdir - this deletes empty directories. If you want to delete a directory with stuff in it, first use rm -r and then use rmdir.

rmdir ~/hw01

This deletes the (empty) hw01 directory.

instruction: How do I learn about terminal commands?
response:
man [command] - This lists the manual for a given command, i.e., if you do not know what a command does or would like to learn about flags you can use with a command this is the tool for you.

man grep

This would tell you how to use the grep command.

instruction: What does the cat terminal command do?
response:
cat reads data from a file and gives that data as output (if no piping is used, terminal will use standard output and print to the screen).

cat ~/hw01/daily.cpp

Will display the contents of the daily.cpp file using standard output (so in this case it will be printed on your terminal screen).

instruction: What does the less terminal command do?
response:
less - Another useful tool for looking at the contents of a file. Allows you to preview the text content of files.

less ~/hw01/daily.cpp

Will show the text in this file in a command line viewer. You can scroll through the file to look at it. When you are done, press “q” to exit and return to the command line.

Notice there is a subtle difference between cat and less: cat gives the file’s data as output whereas less allows you to see the data in a viewer but the data is not given as output.

less ~/hw01/daily.cpp

Will show the text in this file in a command line viewer. You can scroll through the file to look at it. When you are done, press “q” to exit and return to the command line.

Notice there is a subtle difference between cat and less: cat gives the file’s data as output whereas less allows you to see the data in a viewer but the data is not given as output.

grep searches for characters/sequences of characters in files and prints out the lines containing those characters/sequences of characters from that file.

grep “e” daily.cpp

The first command finds all lines with e in the file daily.cpp

grep [pattern] [file]

The general format for the command.

For more information on patterns you can use, research Regular Expressions or regex.

nano allows you to view and edit the contents of a file in the nano editor (a command line text editor). 

This is helpful if you cannot access a desktop text editor, perhaps because you have connected to a machine through SSH or can only use it through a command line.

Example usage: nano [file]

instruction: How do I edit a file on a link machine?
response:
First, make sure that you connect to a link machine with the SSH connection feature in VSCode. To do this, click on the icon in the left sidebar that looks like a computer screen with two arrows in a circle in the bottom right corner of the icon. Either add a connection to a link machine or use an existing connection. If the icon is not present, you most likely need to install the SSH extension in VSCode.

Once you are connected to a link machine in VSCode, navigate to the top icon on the left sidebar that looks like documents stacked on each other. Click on that icon and choose “open folder.” Enter the path of the folder you would like to open. Once you do that, all the files in that folder will appear in the left sidebar. Simply double click one to open and begin editing it.

instruction: What does the find terminal command do?
response:
find - Allows you to search your computer for a specific file (by filename, user, or other operands), either from the root directory (meaning it will examine every file) or in a directory you specify.

Two common operands to use with find:

-name: Find files matching a specific name pattern
-type: Find files matching a specific type (pass b for block special file, c for character special file, d for directory, l for symbolic link, p for FIFO, f for regular file, and s for socket).

More operands can be found by researching find or using the command man find.

Example usage:

Find the file homework.txt, searching your home directory: 
find ~ -name homework.txt

Find the file homework.txt, searching the root directory:
find / -name homework.txt

Find the file homework.txt, searching your cs221 directory (and any subdirectories within it):
find ~/cs221 -name homework.txt

Find all .cpp files in your cs221 directory:
find ~/cs221 -name *.cpp

For more information on the wildcard (*), research regex wildcards.
Find all directories in your cs221 directory:
find ~/cs221 -type d

Find all directories beginning with hw in your cs221 directory:
find ~/cs221 -name hw* -type d

find ~/cs221 -name homework.txt

instruction: How do I push to git?
response:
If you would like to push files to git, there are a few steps. The first step is to add your files to be committed. You can do this by entering the following command:

git add [filenames, separated by spaces] 

Then, you need to commit your files by entering the following command:

git commit -m “some message”

Make sure to include a commit message in quotations after the -m. This message should be related to the files you are changing, such as “updated file1” or “hw01 submission.”

Next, make sure the link machine/your personal computer is up to date with the repository by pulling from the repository. You can do this by running the following command:

git pull origin main

If you are working with a different git branch, you can use git pull origin [branch].

If that command is successful, then you can push to git using the following command:

git push origin main

Again, if you are using a branch, you can replace main with the branch name.

If you would like to push files to git, there are a few steps. The first step is to add your files to be committed. You can do this by entering the following command:

git add [filenames, separated by spaces] 

Then, you need to commit your files by entering the following command:

git commit -m “some message”

Make sure to include a commit message in quotations after the -m. This message should be related to the files you are changing, such as “updated file1” or “hw01 submission.”

Next, make sure the link machine/your personal computer is up to date with the repository by pulling from the repository. You can do this by running the following command:

git pull origin main

If you are working with a different git branch, you can use git pull origin [branch].

If that command is successful, then you can push to git using the following command:

git push origin main

Again, if you are using a branch, you can replace main with the branch name.

instruction: What is a link machine?
response:
The link machines are computers running Linux in RNS202 and RNS203. You connect to them remotely with your computer using SSH. They come with all the necessary software and code compilers installed so you can complete your coursework without having to worry about extra headaches!

You can connect to a link machine by running the following command:

ssh [username]@rns20[2-3]-[1-20].cs.stolaf.edu

Where you replace [username] with your St. Olaf username (no brackets) and pick a number between 2-3 and 1-20 for the other portions (no brackets). For instance, if to access link machine 5 in rns202, use rns202-5.cs.stolaf.edu

ssh [username]@rns20[2-3]-[1-20].cs.stolaf.edu

Where you replace [username] with your St. Olaf username (no brackets) and pick a number between 2-3 and 1-20 for the other portions (no brackets). For instance, if to access link machine 5 in rns202, use rns202-5.cs.stolaf.edu

instruction: How do I find csgit?
response:
First, either on the St. Olaf eduroam network or using the St. Olaf VPN go to csgit.stolaf.edu. Sign in with your username (NOT your email) and password. 

Once you have signed in, you will see all your repositories for the courses you have taken. Click on the one you would like to access.

To clone to a link machine or personal computer, on the csgit website click the blue “Code” button and copy the SSH url. 

Then, in a terminal on the link machine or personal computer, go to the empty directory/folder you would like to clone the repo to and enter the following command:

git clone [paste the SSH url here, no brackets] .

Don’t forget the period at the end of the command!

instruction: What is SSH?
response:
SSH (Secure Shell) is used for managing networks, operating systems, and configurations. It is also inside many file transfer tools and configuration management tools. Every major corporation uses it, in every data center.

SSH keys enable the automation that makes modern cloud services and other computer-dependent services possible and cost-effective. They offer convenience and improved security when properly managed.

Functionally SSH keys resemble passwords. They grant access and control who can access what. In identity and access management, they need similar policies, provisioning, and termination as user accounts and passwords. One cannot have confidentiality, integrity, or any guarantees of continued availability of systems without controlling SSH keys.

Technically the keys are cryptographic keys using a public key cryptosystem. However, functionally they are authentication credentials and need to be managed as such.

Technically the keys are cryptographic keys using a public key cryptosystem. However, functionally they are authentication credentials and need to be managed as such.

instruction: How do I create an SSH key?
response:
First, check if you have an SSH key already created on the link machine. You can do this on a link machine or Mac by running the command:

cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

If there is output, that is your public SSH key and what you are looking for. If there is an error such as: file not found, continue with the following steps.

Begin by entering the following command in your terminal: 

ssh-keygen -t rsa

Then, you can run the following to get your key:

cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

instruction: How to fix SSH connection refused error
response:
1. Check if your machine’s SSH service is down. You can do that by entering the following

sudo service status ssh

If the command line returns that the ssh service is down, that is most likely your error. To solve it, research how to enable SSH on Mac/Windows/Linux depending on the operating system your personal computer is running.

2. You may be using the wrong credentials. Double check that the hostname, your username and your password are all typed correctly. For connecting to link machines, the hostname should follow the form: rns20[2-3]-[1-20].cs.stolaf.edu where in each set of brackets you pick a number in the range and then omit the brackets from the hostname.

3. If the above steps do not work, try the following. On your personal machine, enter the following command:

ssh -Q mac

A list will print. One potential output looks something like: hmac-sha1. Next, instead of running the standard ssh command, run this command instead, using the first entry in the list you just generated:

ssh -m [first entry from list] username@rns20[2-3]-[1-20].cs.stolaf.edu

Where everything in brackets is replaced and the brackets are not included in the command. Repeat the above command with other entries in the list you generated until one of them works.

instruction: SSH Warning: Remote Host Identification has changed
response:
To fix this issue, enter the following command on your personal computer:

ssh-keygen -R [hostname] 

Where hostname is the name of the machine you are trying to connect to. If you are trying to connect to rns202-1.cs.stolaf.edu and get this error, on your personal computer you would use:

ssh-keygen -R rns202-1.cs.stolaf.edu 

After running the command, use the normal SSH command to connect to the machine.

instruction: What is a for loop?
response:
The For loop is used in many imperative programming languages notably Python, C and C++ and comes from the English word 'for' which is used to state the purpose of an object or action, in this case the purpose and details of the iteration.

For loops are generally used when the number of iterations is known or already established. For loops in different languages differ mainly by syntax and how the statements work as well as the level of expressiveness supported.

For example, in Python, you could write a for loop like this:

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  print(x)

And this prints “apple,” “banana,” and “cherry.”

For loops are generally used when the number of iterations is known or already established. For loops in different languages differ mainly by syntax and how the statements work as well as the level of expressiveness supported.

For example, in Python, you could write a for loop like this:

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  print(x)

And this prints “apple,” “banana,” and “cherry.”

instruction: What is a while loop?
response:
A while loop is a control flow statement which repeatedly executes a block of code until the condition is satisfied. It stops executing the block only if the condition fails. One should use a 'while' loop when one needs to perform a repeated operation, but doesn't know in advance how many iterations would be needed.

For example, in Python, you could write a while loop like this:

i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  i += 1

This ends up printing 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

instruction: How do I resolve merge conflicts?
response:
To resolve a merge conflict caused by competing line changes, you must choose which changes to incorporate from the different branches in a new commit.

For example, if you and another person both edited the file styleguide.md on the same lines in different branches of the same Git repository, you'll get a merge conflict error when you try to merge these branches. You must resolve this merge conflict with a new commit before you can merge these branches.

1. Open Terminal.

2. Navigate into the local Git repository that has the merge conflict.

3. Generate a list of the files affected by the merge conflict using the command git status

4. Open your favorite text editor, such as Visual Studio Code, and navigate to the file that has merge conflicts.

5. To see the beginning of the merge conflict in your file, search the file for the conflict marker <<<<<<<. When you open the file in your text editor, you'll see the changes from the HEAD or base branch after the line <<<<<<< HEAD. Next, you'll see =======, which divides your changes from the changes in the other branch, followed by >>>>>>> BRANCH-NAME. In this example, one person wrote "open an issue" in the base or HEAD branch and another person wrote "ask your question in IRC" in the compare branch or branch-a.

If you have questions, please
<<<<<<< HEAD
open an issue
=======
ask your question in IRC.
>>>>>>> branch-a

6. Decide if you want to keep only your branch's changes, keep only the other branch's changes, or make a brand new change, which may incorporate changes from both branches. Delete the conflict markers <<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>> and make the changes you want in the final merge. In this example, both changes are incorporated into the final merge:

7. Add and commit your new file!

instruction: What are branches in git?
response: In Git, branches are a part of your everyday development process. Git branches are effectively a pointer to a snapshot of your changes. When you want to add a new feature or fix a bug—no matter how big or how small—you spawn a new branch to encapsulate your changes. This is especially useful when working on projects with multiple people because it allows you to avoid merge conflicts. If multiple people are working on main and make different changes to a file, a merge conflict arises. However, if multiple people are working on the same file but on different branches, no merge conflict arises.

instruction: How do I create a branch in git?
response: To create a new branch, use the command: git branch [branch name] where branch name is the name of the branch (exclude the brackets). To change to that new branch, use the command: git checkout [branch name]. Now your adds, commits, and pushes will be on that branch.

instruction: How do I merge a branch into main on git?
response:
First, make sure you are on the main branch. To change to the main branch, run: git checkout main. Then, run git fetch and git pull origin main to make sure everything is up to date before merging. Once you have run those commands, merge the branch using the following command:

git merge [branch name]

You may have to resolve some merge conflicts. You can either ask this chatbot how to fix merge conflicts or research it.

Then, while not required, it is highly recommended you delete the branch after merging to main. You can do that by using the command: git branch -d [branch name]

instruction: What is a class?
response: In object-oriented programming, a class is a template definition containing methods (functions) and variables for a particular kind of object. Thus, an object is a specific instance of a class; it contains real values instead of variables. The class is one of the defining ideas of object-oriented programming. For instance, there may be a rectangle class that has variables height and width as well as a perimeter and area method to calculate the perimeter and area using the height and width variables.

instruction: What is an object?
response: An object can be defined as a data field that has unique attributes and behavior. Usually, classes are used to create objects. Object oriented programming focuses on the objects that developers want to manipulate rather than the logic required to manipulate them. This approach to programming is well-suited for programs that are large, complex and actively updated or maintained.

instruction: What is a method?
response: A method in object-oriented programming is a procedure associated with a class. One way to think about it is it is a function specific to a class. A method defines the behavior of the objects that are created from the class. Another way to say this is that a method is an action that an object is able to perform.

instruction: What is object oriented programming?
response:
Object-oriented programming (OOP) is a computer programming model that organizes software design around data, or objects, rather than functions and logic. An object can be defined as a data field that has unique attributes and behavior.

OOP focuses on the objects that developers want to manipulate rather than the logic required to manipulate them. This approach to programming is well-suited for programs that are large, complex and actively updated or maintained. This includes programs for manufacturing and design, as well as mobile applications; for example, OOP can be used for manufacturing system simulation software.

The organization of an object-oriented program also makes the method beneficial to collaborative development, where projects are divided into groups. Additional benefits of OOP include code reusability, scalability and efficiency.

instruction: What is piping in terminal?
response:
Generally, a pipe is a form of redirecting output to another destination for further processing. It provides a temporary connection between two or more commands, programs or processes. In Unix and Linux systems, a pipe enables more complex processing. A pipe can also be used to combine two or more commands or programs. For example, if I want to sort the lines in a file and display a unique list of them, I can pipe the sort and uniq command like this:

sort record.txt | uniq

Here, the output from sort record.txt is used as the input for uniq.

response:
Generally, a pipe is a form of redirecting output to another destination for further processing. It provides a temporary connection between two or more commands, programs or processes. In Unix and Linux systems, a pipe enables more complex processing. A pipe can also be used to combine two or more commands or programs. For example, if I want to sort the lines in a file and display a unique list of them, I can pipe the sort and uniq command like this:

sort record.txt | uniq

Here, the output from sort record.txt is used as the input for uniq.

instruction: What is machine learning?
response: Machine learning is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) and computer science which focuses on the use of data and algorithms to create models to imitate the way that humans learn, gradually improving its accuracy. For instance, machine learning might be used to create a model that based on images of handwritten 2s and 7s can predict whether it is a 2 or a 7.

instruction: What is deep learning?
response: Deep learning is a method in artificial intelligence (AI) that teaches computers to process data in a way that is inspired by the human brain. Deep learning models can recognize complex patterns in pictures, text, sounds, and other data to produce accurate insights and predictions. You can use deep learning methods to automate tasks that typically require human intelligence, such as describing images or transcribing a sound file into text. This chatbot was created using deep learning and transformer models!

instruction: What is a tree?
response:
A tree data structure is a hierarchical structure that is used to represent and organize data in a way that is easy to navigate and search. It is a collection of nodes that are connected by edges and has a hierarchical relationship between the nodes. 

The topmost node of the tree is called the root, and the nodes below it are called the child nodes. Each node can have multiple child nodes, and these child nodes can also have their own child nodes, forming a recursive structure.

instruction: What is a queue?
response: A queue is a container of objects (a linear collection) that are inserted and removed according to the first-in first-out (FIFO) principle. An excellent example of a queue is a line of students to get into Stav during the lunch rush: the first person in line will be the first person to get into Stav!

instruction: What is a stack?
response: Stack is a linear data structure that follows a particular order in which the operations are performed. The order may be LIFO(Last In First Out) or FILO(First In Last Out). LIFO implies that the element that is inserted last, comes out first and FILO implies that the element that is inserted first, comes out last.

instruction: How to fix a syntax error?
response:
A SyntaxError occurs in a language when the interpreter is unable to parse the code due to the code violating languages language rules, such as inappropriate indentation, erroneous keyword usage, or incorrect operator use. Syntax errors prohibit the code from running, and the interpreter displays an error message that specifies the problem and where it occurred in the code.

The syntax error will point out where the error occurred–for instance it may say in line two unexpected ‘:’ which means there should not be a colon there. Many times it gives a suggestion of something is missing as well. So read the error closely–most likely the solution is given to you in the error!

A SyntaxError occurs in a language when the interpreter is unable to parse the code due to the code violating languages language rules, such as inappropriate indentation, erroneous keyword usage, or incorrect operator use. Syntax errors prohibit the code from running, and the interpreter displays an error message that specifies the problem and where it occurred in the code.

The syntax error will point out where the error occurred–for instance it may say in line two unexpected ‘:’ which means there should not be a colon there. Many times it gives a suggestion of something is missing as well. So read the error closely–most likely the solution is given to you in the error!

instruction: How to fix a name error?
response: A NameError is raised when the interpreter encounters a variable or function name that it cannot find in the current scope. This can happen for a variety of reasons, such as misspelling a variable or function name, using a variable or function before it is defined, or referencing a variable or function that is outside the current scope. Check where you have defined your variables and how they are spelled to fix this error!

instruction: How to fix a type error?
response: A TypeError is raised when an operation or function is applied to an object of an inappropriate type. This can happen when trying to perform arithmetic or logical operations on incompatible data types or when passing arguments of the wrong type to a function. For example, if you try to add a string and an integer, the compiler does not know what you are trying to do so a TypeError will be raised. To fix it, make sure the functions or operations you are using are compatible with the variables you are using them with.

instruction: How to fix an index error?
response: An IndexError is raised when we try to access an index of a sequence (such as a string, list, or tuple) that is out of range. This can happen when we try to access an element that doesn't exist in the sequence or when we try to access an element at an index that is greater than or equal to the length of the sequence. For example, if you have an array of four elements and try to index the tenth element, which doesn’t exist, you will get an index error. If you get an index error, make sure to check how big the variable you are trying to index is!

instruction: How to fix an attribute error?
response: An AttributeError is raised when you try to access an attribute or method of an object that does not exist or is not defined for that object. This can happen when you misspell the name of an attribute or method or when you try to access an attribute or method that is not defined for the type of object you are working with. For example, if you have a string called myString and try to call myString.reverse() in Python, you will receive an attribute error since there is not a reverse() method for strings. To fix an attribute error, check the spelling of methods (i.e. that reverse is called correctly) and that you can actually use that method on the object.

instruction: How to fix a value error?
response: A ValueError is raised when a function receives an argument of the correct type but an inappropriate value. For instance, in Python if you are using the square root function and pass a negative number as an argument, you will get a value error. While a negative number is still a number (and thus the correct type), you cannot take the square root of a negative number. To fix a value error, check what your functions are doing and if it can handle the arguments you pass to it.

instruction: How to fix the undeclared identifier error?
response: If you receive this error, it means you are trying to use a function/variable/class in your code but the compiler cannot find its definition and thus does not know what that function/variable/class is. This is usually caused if you forgot to include the header file containing the definitions of that function/variable/class or you misspelled the name of the identifier (either in the definition or the use).

instruction: How to fix the undefined reference error?
response: This occurs when you use a function/class/variable but the C++ linker cannot find its definition. This error usually occurs when working with .o files. The usual reasons this error occurs is you forgot to link the .o file containing the definition, you misspelled the definition or use of the function/class/variable, or everything is spelled correctly and the order of parameters in the definition does not match the order of the arguments in the call.

instruction: What is a segmentation fault?
response:
A Segmentation fault is a specific kind of error caused by accessing memory that “does not belong to you.” It’s a helper mechanism that keeps you from corrupting the memory and introducing hard-to-debug memory bugs. Whenever you get a segfault you know you are doing something wrong with memory – accessing a variable that has already been freed, writing to a read-only portion of the memory, etc.

A few common ways to get a segmentation fault is to dereference a null pointer, try to write to a portion of the memory marked as read-only (i.e. using char or const in the pointer declaration), use dangling pointers, meaning a pointer points to something that no longer exists (this usually happens when pointers are declared and used in different scopes), or improperly allocate and free dynamic memory.

Here is a list of steps to take to try and resolve a segmentation fault:

1. Check that you are not trying to modify a string literal. This means you are trying to modify a string that was declared using char, making it read only. If this is the case, either remove char from the declaration or do not attempt to modify the string.

2. Check if you are trying to access an address that has been freed. For instance, if you have allocated something in dynamic memory and then deleted it, you cannot try to access it again. Similarly, if you are using dynamic memory and have forgotten to call delete once you are done with it, this can also cause a segmentation fault.

3. Are you accessing an out-of-bounds array index? In C and C++, there is no array bounds checking, so if you have an array of four items and try to access an element at position 6, a segmentation fault can occur. Many times a program tries to access an element in an array that is just beyond the bounds of an array, usually due to an error in a loop declaration.

4. It may be due to stack overflow. While this is not a common problem, this can occur if you run out of memory in your stack. It is also a type of memory corruption that may happen due to large array size, a large number of recursive calls, lots of local variables, etc. This segmentation fault may be raised even if you don’t have any pointers in your code.

5. You may also receive a segmentation fault due to buffer overflows. If the data being stored in the buffer is larger than the allocated size of the buffer, a buffer overflow occurs which leads to the segmentation fault. Most of the methods in the C language do not perform bound checking, so buffer overflow happens frequently when we forget to allot the required size to the buffer.

6. If you try to dereference a null or uninitialized pointer you will also get a segmentation fault.

7. If using dynamic memory, remember that for every new call there should be a corresponding delete call!

It is also a type of memory corruption that may happen due to large array size, a large number of recursive calls, lots of local variables, etc. This segmentation fault may be raised even if you don’t have any pointers in your code.

5. You may also receive a segmentation fault due to buffer overflows. If the data being stored in the buffer is larger than the allocated size of the buffer, a buffer overflow occurs which leads to the segmentation fault. Most of the methods in the C language do not perform bound checking, so buffer overflow happens frequently when we forget to allot the required size to the buffer.

6. If you try to dereference a null or uninitialized pointer you will also get a segmentation fault.

7. If using dynamic memory, remember that for every new call there should be a corresponding delete call!

instruction: What's the definition of a segmentation fault?
response:
A Segmentation fault is a specific kind of error caused by accessing memory that “does not belong to you.” It’s a helper mechanism that keeps you from corrupting the memory and introducing hard-to-debug memory bugs. Whenever you get a segfault you know you are doing something wrong with memory – accessing a variable that has already been freed, writing to a read-only portion of the memory, etc.

A few common ways to get a segmentation fault is to dereference a null pointer, try to write to a portion of the memory marked as read-only (i.e. using char or const in the pointer declaration), use dangling pointers, meaning a pointer points to something that no longer exists (this usually happens when pointers are declared and used in different scopes), or improperly allocate and free dynamic memory.

Here is a list of steps to take to try and resolve a segmentation fault:

1. Check that you are not trying to modify a string literal. This means you are trying to modify a string that was declared using char, making it read only. If this is the case, either remove char from the declaration or do not attempt to modify the string.

2. Check if you are trying to access an address that has been freed. For instance, if you have allocated something in dynamic memory and then deleted it, you cannot try to access it again. Similarly, if you are using dynamic memory and have forgotten to call delete once you are done with it, this can also cause a segmentation fault.

3. Are you accessing an out-of-bounds array index? In C and C++, there is no array bounds checking, so if you have an array of four items and try to access an element at position 6, a segmentation fault can occur. Many times a program tries to access an element in an array that is just beyond the bounds of an array, usually due to an error in a loop declaration.

4. It may be due to stack overflow. While this is not a common problem, this can occur if you run out of memory in your stack. It is also a type of memory corruption that may happen due to large array size, a large number of recursive calls, lots of local variables, etc. This segmentation fault may be raised even if you don’t have any pointers in your code.

5. You may also receive a segmentation fault due to buffer overflows. If the data being stored in the buffer is larger than the allocated size of the buffer, a buffer overflow occurs which leads to the segmentation fault. Most of the methods in the C language do not perform bound checking, so buffer overflow happens frequently when we forget to allot the required size to the buffer.

6. If you try to dereference a null or uninitialized pointer you will also get a segmentation fault.

7. If using dynamic memory, remember that for every new call there should be a corresponding delete call!

instruction: I can't access csgit
response:
There are a couple of reasons you might not be able to use csgit. The first thing to check is that your personal computer is on eduroam or using the St. Olaf VPN. If you are not using either of these tools, you will not be able to access csgit. 

If you are on the eduroam network or using the St. Olaf VPN, the next most likely reason you cannot access csgit is your SSH key has changed (on your personal computer) or expired (on csgit). Use this chatbot to learn more about SSH keys or research SSH keys to fix this issue!

instruction: How to add my SSH key to csgit?
response:
1. On a link machine terminal, enter the following command:

cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

or
                   
less ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

NOTE: If you do not have a id_rsa.pub file,  type ssh-keygen -t rsa and just hit enter when it asks for a passphrase. Then rerun the command from step 1.

2. Copy the output from the command entered in step 1.

3. On CSgit (csgit.stolaf.edu), click on your profile icon > Preferences > SSH Keys

4. Click Add Key in the top right of the table. In the big box, paste the terminal output you copied in step 2. In the title box, just enter a name (like link machine, or my PC, or something like that). Leave the usage type at its default. DELETE THE EXPIRATION DATE, otherwise you will have to repeat this process every year. Then add the key.

instruction: How do I set up SSH in VSCode?
response:
The first step is to make sure you are either on campus using the eduroam network or using the St. Olaf VPN.

To be able to connect to the St. Olaf links machines with VSCode on your personal computer, you need to set up SSH. To start, open VSCode, and on the left side of the window open the extensions tab (the icon with four squares at the end of the list of icons).

In the search bar that appears in the extensions tab, search for “ssh.” Select “Remote - SSH” when it appears (it should be near the top and is created by Microsoft).

Install the extension, and follow any instructions during the installation process. Once it has been installed, quit and relaunch VSCode (just to make sure everything is configured correctly). You should now see a new icon above the extensions icon that has a screen with arrows in a circle. Select that icon. It will bring up the remote explorer tab (the icon looks like a computer with greater than and less than signs in the bottom right corner).

In the remote explorer tab, make sure SSH Targets is selected in the top dropdown menu and you see the SSH Targets list underneath. To add an SSH connection, hover over the SSH Targets list header, and then click the plus that appears to the right of that heading.

In the prompt that appears, type:

ssh username@rns20x-y.cs.stolaf.edu

where you replace username with your St. Olaf username, x with either 2 or 3 (for RNS 202 and 203), and y with a number in the range 1-27. These correspond to each link machine in RNS 202 and 203. Then hit enter. 

In the next screen that appears, just press enter again, you want to update your default SSH configuration profile.

After you have done that, you will see the host added in the remote explorer tab under SSH Targets.

Next, hover over the name of the host and you will see a little button appear to the right of the name that looks like a window with a plus. Click that button.

A new window will pop up. You may receive a prompt asking you to select the platform of the remote host. If so, select Linux. Also, if this is the first time you are connecting to the host, you will receive a prompt talking about a fingerprint. Select Continue. 

It will then ask you for your password (this is your St. Olaf password). 

Once you have entered your password, you can tell if you are connected to the link machine by looking in the bottom left corner and verifying that the name of the link machine is listed there.


If at any point you get a connection refused error, try the following steps:

Check if your machine’s SSH service is down. You can do that by entering the following sudo service status ssh If the command line returns that the ssh service is down, that is most likely your error. To solve it, research how to enable SSH on Mac/Windows/Linux depending on the operating system your personal computer is running. 

You may be using the wrong credentials. Double check that the hostname, your username and your password are all typed correctly. For connecting to link machines, the hostname should follow the form: 

rns20[2-3]-[1-20].cs.stolaf.edu 

where in each set of brackets you pick a number in the range and then omit the brackets from the hostname.

If the above steps do not work, try the following. On your personal machine, enter the following command: 

ssh -Q mac 

A list will print. One potential output looks something like: hmac-sha1. Next, instead of running the standard ssh command, run this command instead, using the first entry in the list you just generated: 

ssh -m [first entry from list] username@rns20[2-3]-[1-20].cs.stolaf.edu 

Where everything in brackets is replaced and the brackets are not included in the command. Repeat the above command with other entries in the list you generated until one of them works. To try with hmac-sha1 on the rns202-1 link machine, the command would be:

ssh -m hmac-sha1 username@rns202-1.cs.stolaf.edu

response:
The first step is to make sure you are either on campus using the eduroam network or using the St. Olaf VPN.

To be able to connect to the St. Olaf links machines with VSCode on your personal computer, you need to set up SSH. To start, open VSCode, and on the left side of the window open the extensions tab (the icon with four squares at the end of the list of icons).

In the search bar that appears in the extensions tab, search for “ssh.” Select “Remote - SSH” when it appears (it should be near the top and is created by Microsoft).

Install the extension, and follow any instructions during the installation process. Once it has been installed, quit and relaunch VSCode (just to make sure everything is configured correctly). You should now see a new icon above the extensions icon that has a screen with arrows in a circle. Select that icon. It will bring up the remote explorer tab (the icon looks like a computer with greater than and less than signs in the bottom right corner).

In the remote explorer tab, make sure SSH Targets is selected in the top dropdown menu and you see the SSH Targets list underneath. To add an SSH connection, hover over the SSH Targets list header, and then click the plus that appears to the right of that heading.

In the prompt that appears, type:

ssh username@rns20x-y.cs.stolaf.edu

where you replace username with your St. Olaf username, x with either 2 or 3 (for RNS 202 and 203), and y with a number in the range 1-27. These correspond to each link machine in RNS 202 and 203. Then hit enter. 

In the next screen that appears, just press enter again, you want to update your default SSH configuration profile.

After you have done that, you will see the host added in the remote explorer tab under SSH Targets.

Next, hover over the name of the host and you will see a little button appear to the right of the name that looks like a window with a plus. Click that button.

A new window will pop up. You may receive a prompt asking you to select the platform of the remote host. If so, select Linux. Also, if this is the first time you are connecting to the host, you will receive a prompt talking about a fingerprint. Select Continue. 

It will then ask you for your password (this is your St. Olaf password). 

Once you have entered your password, you can tell if you are connected to the link machine by looking in the bottom left corner and verifying that the name of the link machine is listed there.


If at any point you get a connection refused error, try the following steps:

Check if your machine’s SSH service is down. You can do that by entering the following sudo service status ssh If the command line returns that the ssh service is down, that is most likely your error. To solve it, research how to enable SSH on Mac/Windows/Linux depending on the operating system your personal computer is running. 

You may be using the wrong credentials. Double check that the hostname, your username and your password are all typed correctly. For connecting to link machines, the hostname should follow the form: 

rns20[2-3]-[1-20].cs.stolaf.edu 

where in each set of brackets you pick a number in the range and then omit the brackets from the hostname.

If the above steps do not work, try the following. On your personal machine, enter the following command: 

ssh -Q mac 

A list will print. One potential output looks something like: hmac-sha1. Next, instead of running the standard ssh command, run this command instead, using the first entry in the list you just generated: 

ssh -m [first entry from list] username@rns20[2-3]-[1-20].cs.stolaf.edu 

Where everything in brackets is replaced and the brackets are not included in the command. Repeat the above command with other entries in the list you generated until one of them works. To try with hmac-sha1 on the rns202-1 link machine, the command would be:

ssh -m hmac-sha1 username@rns202-1.cs.stolaf.edu

instruction: What is a function?
response: A function is a block of organized, reusable code that is used to perform a single, related action. Functions provide better modularity for your application and a high degree of code reusing. Functions usually "take in" data, process it, and "return" a result. Once a function is written, it can be used over and over and over again.

Functions provide better modularity for your application and a high degree of code reusing. Functions usually "take in" data, process it, and "return" a result. Once a function is written, it can be used over and over and over again.

instruction: What is the difference between a function and a function call?
response: A function is a block of code that performs a specific task, while a function call is an expression that invokes a function and executes the code in the function. For instance, if you write a function multiply(x, y) and write the code to multiply the two numbers x and y together, that is the function. The function call would be in your code using multiply(2,3) to multiply 2 and 3.

instruction: What is the difference between parameters and arguments?
response: The values that are declared within a function when the function is called are known as an argument. Whereas, the variables that are defined when the function is declared are known as a parameter. For example, if you have written a function multiply(x, y) that multiplies two numbers x and y together, x and y are the parameters of the function. When you call the function multiply(2, 3), 2 and 3 are the arguments of the function.

instruction: What is a string?
response:
A string is a data type used in programming, that is used to represent text rather than numbers. A string is a sequence of characters and can contain letters, numbers, symbols and even spaces. It must be enclosed in quotation marks for it to be recognized as a string.

For example, the word “liquid” and the phrase “What is liquid? It’s a template language.” are both strings. Even the sequence of characters “98OkJJ$%janUJ£” is considered a string.

instruction: What is a char?
response: The char data type is used to store a single character. The character must be surrounded by single quotes, like 'A' or 'c'. On Linux machines It can also be used to store numbers -128 to 127 or 0 to 255 if it is an unsigned char. It can store 8 bits in memory.

instruction: What is a long?
response: In C++, long is a data type for a constant or variable which has the capability of storing the variable or constant values with 64-bits storage (on Linux machines) and is signed integer data type which is used for storing variable or constants with larger values larger than standard integer 32-bit data type.

instruction: What is a bool?
response: Boolean means a result that can only have one of two possible values: true or false. Most programming languages have True and False keywords that can be used to set boolean variables. It is also acceptable in most languages to use 0 as false and 1 as true.

instruction: What is a const?
response: The const keyword in C++ specifies that a variable's value is constant and tells the compiler to prevent the programmer from modifying it. Use this for variables that are intended to be set once and never changed. The compiler will throw an error if this variable is changed after its declaration.

instruction: What is an array?
response: An array is a collection of items of the same data type stored at contiguous memory locations. You create an array by surrounding the items in brackets. In C++, the size of an array is fixed unless you use dynamic memory allocation.

instruction: What is a vector?
response: In C++, vectors are used to store elements of similar data types. However, unlike arrays, the size of a vector can grow dynamically. That is, we can change the size of the vector during the execution of a program as per our requirements.

instruction: What is a dictionary?
response: A dictionary is a kind of data structure that stores items in key-value pairs. A key is a unique identifier for an item, and a value is the data associated with that key. Dictionaries often store information such as words and definitions, but they can be used for much more. You create a dictionary using curly braces and separating the keys and values with a colon.

instruction: What are some common data types in C++?
response:
In C++, there are different types of variables (defined with different keywords), for example:

int - stores integers (whole numbers), without decimals, such as 123 or -123
double - stores floating point numbers, with decimals, such as 19.99 or -19.99
char - stores single characters, such as 'a' or 'B'. Char values are surrounded by single quotes
string - stores text, such as "Hello World". String values are surrounded by double quotes
bool - stores values with two states: true or false

instruction: What are some common errors in C++?
response:
The most common errors can be broadly classified as follows: 

Syntax Error - Errors that occur when you violate the rules of writing C/C++ syntax are known as syntax errors. This compiler error indicates something that must be fixed before the code can be compiled. All these errors are detected by the compiler and thus are known as compile-time errors. 
Run-time Error - Errors which occur during program execution(run-time) after successful compilation are called run-time errors. One of the most common run-time errors is division by zero also known as Division error. These types of error are hard to find as the compiler doesn’t point to the line at which the error occurs. 
Linker Error - This error occurs when after compilation we link the different object files with main’s object using Ctrl+F9 key(RUN). These are errors generated when the executable of the program cannot be generated. This may be due to wrong function prototyping, incorrect header files. One of the most common linker errors is writing Main() instead of main(). 
Logical Error - On compilation and execution of a program, desired output is not obtained when certain input values are given. These types of errors which provide incorrect output but appear to be error free are called logical errors. These are one of the most common errors made by beginners of programming. 
Semantic Error - This error occurs when the statements written in the program are not meaningful to the compiler.

One of the most common linker errors is writing Main() instead of main(). 
Logical Error - On compilation and execution of a program, desired output is not obtained when certain input values are given. These types of errors which provide incorrect output but appear to be error free are called logical errors. These are one of the most common errors made by beginners of programming. 
Semantic Error - This error occurs when the statements written in the program are not meaningful to the compiler.

instruction: What are the prevalent errors in C++ development?
response:
The most common errors can be broadly classified as follows: 

Syntax Error - Errors that occur when you violate the rules of writing C/C++ syntax are known as syntax errors. This compiler error indicates something that must be fixed before the code can be compiled. All these errors are detected by the compiler and thus are known as compile-time errors. 
Run-time Error - Errors which occur during program execution(run-time) after successful compilation are called run-time errors. One of the most common run-time errors is division by zero also known as Division error. These types of error are hard to find as the compiler doesn’t point to the line at which the error occurs. 
Linker Error - This error occurs when after compilation we link the different object files with main’s object using Ctrl+F9 key(RUN). These are errors generated when the executable of the program cannot be generated. This may be due to wrong function prototyping, incorrect header files. One of the most common linker errors is writing Main() instead of main().

Semantic Error - This error occurs when the statements written in the program are not meaningful to the compiler.

instruction: What is printing?
response: Printing is the simplest way to get data from a program. It sends this data to standard output so it is displayed in the console/terminal. In Python, you use the print() function. In C, you use the printf function.  In C++, you use cout.

response: In Python, the print() function is used to print the desired message on a device’s screen. The Print is always in a string format. Before being printed the objects gets converted to a string.

instruction: What is returning in a function?
response:
The return statement ends function execution and specifies a value to be returned to the function caller. This means once a return statement is reached, the function does not execute any other lines of code and sends the specified value back to the caller. For instance, a sqrt(x) function would return the square root of x so you could use the following syntax:

y = sqrt(x)

Where y now holds the returned value from sqrt(x).

instruction: What does break do?
response: The break keyword allows you to exit a loop when an external condition is met. Normal program execution resumes at the next statement outside of the loop. You can use a break statement with both for loops and while loops. In a nested loop, break will stop execution of the innermost loop. The flow of the program resumes at the next line of code immediately after the block.

instruction: What does continue do?
response: The continue keyword is used to end the current iteration in a for loop (or a while loop), and continues to the next iteration. This is different from the break keyword as it does not stop the loop but rather skips to the next iteration (aka if i is used to iterate in a for loop, i is incremented at the continue keyword and no other code is executed for the old value of i).

instruction: What does private mean in a class?
response: The private keyword is an access specifier. Private means members of a class cannot be accessed (or viewed) from outside the class. This is useful if there are variables or methods that are only used by the class to perform operations and are not intended to be used by other programmers. Note: By default, all members of a class are private if you don't specify an access specifier.

instruction: What is access specifier?
response:
Access specifiers define how the members (attributes and methods) of a class can be accessed. In C++, there are three access specifiers:

public - members are accessible from outside the class

private - members cannot be accessed (or viewed) from outside the class

protected - members cannot be accessed from outside the class, however, they can be accessed in inherited classes.

Note: By default, all members of a class are private if you don't specify an access specifier.

instruction: What is a struct?
response: Structures (also called structs) are a way to group several related variables into one place. Each variable in the structure is known as a member of the structure. Unlike an array, a structure can contain many different data types (int, float, char, etc.). You can create a structure by using the struct keyword and declare each of its members inside curly braces. To access the structure, you must create a variable of it.

instruction: Difference between a class and a struct?
response: In C++, a structure works the same way as a class, except for just two small differences. The most important of them is hiding implementation details. A structure will by default not hide its implementation details from whoever uses it in code, while a class by default hides all its implementation details and will therefore by default prevent the programmer from accessing them. The other major difference between a class and a struct is what they are used for. A class is normally used for data abstraction and inheritance (classes can inherit other classes) whereas structs are mainly used for data grouping. Structs cannot inherit other structs. Classes are not possible to use in C, only in C++, but are generally preferred to structs since they are the key of object oriented programming.

The other major difference between a class and a struct is what they are used for. A class is normally used for data abstraction and inheritance (classes can inherit other classes) whereas structs are mainly used for data grouping. Structs cannot inherit other structs. Classes are not possible to use in C, only in C++, but are generally preferred to structs since they are the key of object oriented programming.

instruction: What is numpy?
response:
NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing in Python. It is especially used in machine learning applications! It is a Python library that provides a multidimensional array object, various derived objects (such as masked arrays and matrices), and an assortment of routines for fast operations on arrays, including mathematical, logical, shape manipulation, sorting, selecting, I/O, discrete Fourier transforms, basic linear algebra, basic statistical operations, random simulation and much more.

At the core of the NumPy package, is the ndarray object. This encapsulates n-dimensional arrays of homogeneous data types, with many operations being performed in compiled code for performance.

response:

pip install numpy

This will download and install the latest version of NumPy from PyPI.

instruction: How do I install a Python package?
response:
You can install packages using PIP! Make sure you have PIP installed on your system (if you have installed Python you should have also installed PIP!)

To download and install a package, open the command line interface and tell PIP to download the package you want by running the following command:

pip install [package name] 

For example, to install NumPy, the command would be:

pip install numpy

instruction: What is a header file?
response:
These are those files that store predefined functions. It contains definitions of functions that you can include or import using a preprocessor directive #include. This preprocessor directive tells the compiler that the header file needs to be processed prior to the compilation. For example, the <iostream> header file in C++ contains the definition of input-output functions.

Header files are used in C++ so that you don’t have to write the code for every single thing. It helps to reduce the complexity and number of lines of code. It also gives you the benefit of reusing the functions that are declared in header files to different .cpp files and including a header file is way easier than writing the implementations. By using a header file, you keep the program precise and focused, which makes it manageable.

instruction: How do I link files in C++?
response:
There are a two ways to do this. For basic linking, you can just include multiple files in the g++ compile command like this:

g++ foo1.cpp foo2.cpp

This produces an executable file a.out where you can use ./a.out to run it. However, we generally use the following method for linking more files as it means a change in one file does not mean every file needs to be recompiled. To do this, you create .o files for each cpp/header file and then link them together. An example is shown here: 

g++ -c foo1.cpp
g++ -c foo2.cpp
g++ -o foo foo1.o foo2.o

This produces an executable file foo where you use ./foo to run it. If you made a change to foo2.cpp, you would only need to rerun:

g++ -c foo2.cpp
g++ -o foo foo1.o foo2.o

since no changes were made to foo1.cpp so foo1.o remains the same.

g++ foo1.cpp foo2.cpp

This produces an executable file a.out where you can use ./a.out to run it. For more advanced linking, i.e. to create .o files for each cpp/header file and then link them together, you can use the following command:

g++ -c foo1.cpp
g++ -c foo2.cpp
g++ -o foo foo1.o foo2.o

This produces an executable file foo where you use ./foo to run it.

instruction: What is the difference between C and C++?
response:
C focuses on procedural programming. It's about following specific steps or instructions. This involves using functions and structured techniques. Essentially, C revolves around functions and the order of program operations.
C++, in contrast, expands on C. It introduces object-oriented programming. This method uses classes and objects. These elements group related functions and data. This approach simplifies complex software design, understanding, and maintenance. The main difference between C and C++ is their approach. C is driven by functions and their execution sequence. C++, however, is based on OOP. It focuses on classes, objects and their interactions. This makes it more suited for handling complex software systems.

instruction: What is an inherited class?
response:
In C++, it is possible to inherit attributes and methods from one class to another. We group the "inheritance concept" into two categories:

derived class (child) - the class that inherits from another class
base class (parent) - the class being inherited from

Usually inheritance is used if one class is a type of another class. For instance, if there is a Rectangle class and a Square class to represent rectangles and squares, since a square is a rectangle, it would make sense for the Square class to inherit the Rectangle class since they share some properties!

Inheritance is also used if there is a base class with methods and variables that are used by many classes but then the derived classes have some specific methods and variables unique to them. This saves code writing time since you only need to write common methods and variables once in the base class!

To inherit from a class, use the : symbol. For example, if I have a class Vehicle and I want the class Car to inherit from the class vehicle, I would define the classes as follows:

class Vehicle { … }

class Car : public Vehicle { … }

There are many useful applications of inheritance, and inheritance is one of the key elements of object oriented programming!

Usually inheritance is used if one class is a type of another class. For instance, if there is a Rectangle class and a Square class to represent rectangles and squares, since a square is a rectangle, it would make sense for the Square class to inherit the Rectangle class since they share some properties!

Inheritance is also used if there is a base class with methods and variables that are used by many classes but then the derived classes have some specific methods and variables unique to them. This saves code writing time since you only need to write common methods and variables once in the base class!

To inherit from a class, use the : symbol. For example, if I have a class Vehicle and I want the class Car to inherit from the class vehicle, I would define the classes as follows:

class Vehicle { … }

class Car : public Vehicle { … }

There are many useful applications of inheritance, and inheritance is one of the key elements of object oriented programming!

instruction: What are Python modules?
response:
A Python module is a file containing Python definitions and statements. A module can define functions, classes, and variables. A module can also include runnable code. 

Grouping related code into a module makes the code easier to understand and use. It also makes the code logically organized.

instruction: How to compile a C++ file
response:
Use the following two commands:

g++ myfile.cpp
./a.out

The g++ command creates an executable file named a.out while the ./a.out runs it. To change the name of the executable file, simply use:

g++ -o name myfile.cpp

Where name is the the desired executable. You can then use ./name to run it.

instruction: How to run a python file
response:
There are a few ways to do this, but the most common one is to use the “Run” feature in your text editor/IDE. You can usually find the “Run” feature by right clicking in the text editor, looking for a play button icon, or looking in the application menus for a Run option. 

The other common way to run a python file is to run it from the command line using the following command:

python myfile.py

Or if that doesn’t work

python3 myfile.py

instruction: How to compile a C file
response:
Compiling a C file is very similar to a C++ file but instead of using g++ you use gcc. Here are the two commands to compile a C file:

gcc myfile.cpp
./a.out

The gcc command creates an executable file named a.out while the ./a.out runs it. To change the name of the executable file, simply use:

gcc -o name myfile.cpp

Where name is the the desired executable. You can then use ./name to run it.

instruction: What is a comment?
response: Comments are text notes added to the program to provide explanatory information about the source code. They are used in a programming language to document the program and remind programmers of what tricky things they just did with the code and also helps the later generation for understanding and maintenance of code. The compiler considers these as non-executable statements. Different programming language uses a different way of including the comments in the source code.

instruction: What is RAM?
response:
RAM is a common computing acronym that stands for random-access memory. Sometimes it’s called PC memory or just memory. In essence, RAM is your computer or laptop’s short-term memory. It’s where the data is stored that your computer processor needs to run your applications and open your files.

Inside your computer, RAM typically comes in the form of a rectangular flat circuit board with memory chips attached, also referred to as a memory module. Computers typically come with at least two RAM modules with room to add more, if needed. These RAM modules are critical components that work hand in hand with your computer’s central processing unit (CPU) and must be working optimally for you to have a good experience.

response:
RAM is a common computing acronym that stands for random-access memory. Sometimes it’s called PC memory or just memory. In essence, RAM is your computer or laptop’s short-term memory. It’s where the data is stored that your computer processor needs to run your applications and open your files.

Inside your computer, RAM typically comes in the form of a rectangular flat circuit board with memory chips attached, also referred to as a memory module. Computers typically come with at least two RAM modules with room to add more, if needed. These RAM modules are critical components that work hand in hand with your computer’s central processing unit (CPU) and must be working optimally for you to have a good experience.

instruction: What is CPU?
response: A central processing unit (CPU) is a hardware component that’s the core computational unit in a computer. Computers and other smart devices convert data into digital signals and perform mathematical operations on them. The CPU is the primary component that processes the signals and makes computing possible. It acts as the brain of any computing device. It fetches instructions from memory, performs the required tasks, and sends output back to memory. It handles all computing tasks required for running the operating system and applications.

instruction: What is an SSD?
response:
A hard drive is a piece of hardware used to store digital content and data on computers. Every computer has an internal hard drive, but you can also get external hard drives that can be used to expand the storage of a computer. 

SSDs (solid state drives) are the newer of the type of hard drive. They have become the preferred format for high-end laptops’ internal hard drives, and all smartphones and tablets also use a form of SSD.

Solid-state drives use flash memory, which is also what’s used in USB flash drives and memory cards for digital cameras. There are no magnets involved here, SSDs use semiconductors that store data by altering the electrical state of the trillions of circuits contained within the SSD. Because they have no moving parts, not only do they work faster (as you don’t need to wait for disks to spin and heads to gather information), they also tend to last longer than HDDs.

SDDs are a lot more expensive to manufacture, so while they’re increasingly prevalent as the primary disk drive for high-end laptops and PCs, hard disk drives are still preferred by many as a cheaper external option.

SSDs (solid state drives) are the newer of the type of hard drive. They have become the preferred format for high-end laptops’ internal hard drives, and all smartphones and tablets also use a form of SSD.

Solid-state drives use flash memory, which is also what’s used in USB flash drives and memory cards for digital cameras. There are no magnets involved here, SSDs use semiconductors that store data by altering the electrical state of the trillions of circuits contained within the SSD. Because they have no moving parts, not only do they work faster (as you don’t need to wait for disks to spin and heads to gather information), they also tend to last longer than HDDs.

SDDs are a lot more expensive to manufacture, so while they’re increasingly prevalent as the primary disk drive for high-end laptops and PCs, hard disk drives are still preferred by many as a cheaper external option.

instruction: What is Linux?
response:
Just like Windows, iOS, and Mac OS, Linux is an operating system. In fact, one of the most popular platforms on the planet, Android, is powered by the Linux operating system. An operating system is software that manages all of the hardware resources associated with your desktop or laptop. To put it simply, the operating system manages the communication between your software and your hardware. Without the operating system (OS), the software wouldn’t function.

There are many different variations of Linux called distros. One of the most popular ones is Ubuntu. Most distros are open source and free to use. Generally, Linux is the preferred operating system for software development and most programming tasks. The link machines run Linux for this reason!

instruction: What is cloud computing?
response: Simply put, cloud computing is the delivery of computing services—including servers, storage, databases, networking, software, analytics, and intelligence—over the internet (“the cloud”) to offer faster innovation, flexible resources, and economies of scale. Instead of buying, owning, and maintaining physical data centers and servers, you can access technology services, such as computing power, storage, and databases, on an as-needed basis from a cloud provider.

instruction: What is a pointer in C++?
response: A pointer is a variable that stores a memory address as its value. A pointer variable points to a data type (like int or string) of the same type, and is created with the * operator. The address of the variable you're working with is assigned to the pointer.

instruction: What is a reference in C++?
response:
A reference variable is a "reference" to an existing variable, and it is created with the & operator. 

For example:

string food = "Pizza";  // food variable
string &meal = food;    // reference to food

Now, we can use either the variable name food or the reference name meal to refer to the food variable.

instruction: What is a memory address in C++?
response:
When a variable is created in C++, a memory address is assigned to the variable. And when we assign a value to the variable, it is stored in this memory address.

To access it, use the & operator, and the result will represent where the variable is stored:

string food = "Pizza";
cout << &food; // Outputs 0x6dfed4

instruction: What is dynamic memory in C++?
response:
Dynamic memory allocation & de-allocation is the process of allocating or de-allocating a block of memory in the course of the execution of a program/ software. This is useful when the size of an array is not known before the execution of a program. 

The new operator is a unary operator used to dynamically allocate a block of memory and keep its address in a pointer variable at some point during the execution of a program. In other words, this operator is like a request for memory allocation on the heap memory (or the free store). And if sufficient memory is available, the dynamic space is initialized to the newly created variable or pointer.

What happens once we do not need the variable that we've got declared dynamically? Well, we must deallocate the space in memory occupied by means of the variable.
For this, we use the delete operator and deallocate the block of memory that was dynamically allotted with the use of the new operator. In view of that, a programmer must de-allocate a block of memory, as soon as it is not required within the program or code or it will lead to memory leaks/segmentation faults. So, we require the delete operator to avoid memory leaks (i.e. segmentation faults). 

For every use of the “new” keyword there should be a use of the “delete” keyword.

The new operator is a unary operator used to dynamically allocate a block of memory and keep its address in a pointer variable at some point during the execution of a program. In other words, this operator is like a request for memory allocation on the heap memory (or the free store). And if sufficient memory is available, the dynamic space is initialized to the newly created variable or pointer.

What happens once we do not need the variable that we've got declared dynamically? Well, we must deallocate the space in memory occupied by means of the variable.
For this, we use the delete operator and deallocate the block of memory that was dynamically allotted with the use of the new operator. In view of that, a programmer must de-allocate a block of memory, as soon as it is not required within the program or code or it will lead to memory leaks/segmentation faults. So, we require the delete operator to avoid memory leaks (i.e. segmentation faults). 

For every “new” keyword there should be a “delete” keyword.
